metadata.titel_preek: Face to Face, Hand in Hand

primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God intervenes in human history to transform the man of dust (Adam) into the man of heaven (Christ), overcoming the ontological barrier of death and sin.

tekstueel_bewijs: God has broken through from beyond human history
God gives it a body as he has chosen
Christ has been raised from the dead

object.identificatie: The Resurrection of the Body / Transformation of Humanity
tekstueel_bewijs: we shall also bear the image of the man of heaven
our sinfulness exchanged for his righteousness

zender.identificatie: God the Father / The 'Other Order' of Reality
tekstueel_bewijs: it does not come from human imagination but from God
all the benefits of Christ's Cross are lost to you

helper.identificatie: The Holy Spirit / The 'Evidence' of the Empty Tomb
tekstueel_bewijs: he gave power to become children of God

tegenstander.identificatie: Death, Sin, the Devil, and the 'Man of Dust' (Perishability)
tekstueel_bewijs: the devil and his hosts destroyed
flesh and blood cannot inherit the kingdom
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent is not a moral failing but an ontological impossibility: the 'perishable' cannot inherit the 'imperishable' without a divine act.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The human response of faith and the recognition of Christ's presence.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Believer / The Hearer
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The human 'grasping' (Secondary) is only possible because God has first 'broken through' (Primary).

voorbeelden_god_subject: God has broken through from beyond human history
God gives it a body as he has chosen
voorbeelden_mens_subject: we shall also bear the image
we today may grasp by faith

voorbeelden: In order to love someone, you have to have them right there
We don't seem to want to believe
We want to hold a warm hand
Paul seeks to remind the Corinthians
he gave power to become children of God
All things are possible with God

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon focuses on the 'Inability' of the human subject (cannot inherit) and the 'Ability' of the Divine subject (all things are possible).

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: From S2 (Dust) through ~S1 (Soul-myth) to S1 (Resurrected Body) via the intervention of the 'Man of Heaven'.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: The tension between dust and heaven is resolved by the 'Exchange' (Substitution) where Christ takes the dust to give the heaven.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: High; death is treated as a total end ('perished') without the Resurrection.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon is profoundly theocentric. It explicitly rejects human capacity (flesh and blood cannot) and places the entire weight of the narrative on God's 'unique action'.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: None found; God is the initiator, not the helper of human effort.

indicatoren_genade.indicator: God as Subject of Active Verbs
indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: God has broken through from beyond human history
the devil and his hosts destroyed

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Biblical figures (Adam/Christ) are used as ontological archetypes, not moral examples to imitate.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon already provides a theocentric reading: Christ is the 'Second Man' who does what the 'First Man' could not.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief and wonder (Awe); moving from 'trembling' to 'joy'.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Soteriology is monergistic; the change is something that 'happens to' the hearer.

narratieve_hierarchie_herstel.voorgestelde_structuur: Soteriology (God raises Christ) → Eschatology (God raises us) → Experience (We grasp by faith).

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: our sinfulness exchanged for his righteousness

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The power is given by God/Christ, though the Spirit is not explicitly named as the agent in this text.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The narrative engine is driven by God's 'Pouvoir' (Power) overcoming human 'Im-pouvoir' (Inability).

modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Maintain current balance; it serves the Easter theme perfectly.
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: The sermon could slightly increase 'Vouloir' by connecting the 'wanting to hold a hand' more deeply to the desire for God.

tegenstander_intensivering.huidige_status: The opponent (Death/Sin) is already treated as an absolute barrier.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: This is a masterclass in grace-oriented preaching. It avoids the trap of turning the Resurrection into a 'spiritual lesson' for self-improvement, keeping the focus on God's cosmic victory.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: While a rhetorical analysis would focus on the 'hand' imagery, Greimas reveals that the 'hand' is an actant of mediation/presence in a larger ontological conflict.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains 1 Cor 15; semiotics shows how the sermon re-enacts the 'exchange' between Adam and Christ for the hearer.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Greimas exposes that the 'Immortality of the Soul' is a narrative 'Opponent' to the 'Resurrection' because it removes the need for a Divine Subject to act on the body.

volledige_subject_lijst: God (gives, has broken through, has chosen)
Christ (has been raised, has borne, is right here)
We (shall bear, shall be changed, may grasp)
appendices.notities: The use of passive voice ('we shall be changed') correctly identifies the hearer as the Receiver of a divine action.
